title: How Do Smurs Help You Learn?
body:
my friend and I are having an argument on, do smurfs help you learn how to play the game better than you would on your main?
I would like to know what you guys think

replies.body:
I think it is almost the opposite (generally).  You play with people on a lot lower of a skill level and it lets you make a lot more mistakes.

The only exception might be it allows you to learn champs you wouldn't otherwise play.

but when you make a smurf it asks if you are you a beginner or have you played ranked and stuff like that

No.  It is asking you if you are familiar with MOBAs in general, not League.  And if you select beginner it will force you to play against bots and show you what the QWER keys do.

 Also, I assume there is a form of normal elo which would pit you against other people of the same level of skill... which would defeat the purpose of creating a new account.  But for the most part you would be stomping someone who has never played the game before.  Which is just cruel.

So I would say the only reason to smurf would be to re-level an account after being banned, creating a new account for ranked, or learning to play a champ your HORRIBLE with.

Yes, smurfing does help, but you have to actually be good enough to learn from it.

What smurfing teaches you is how to carry a game. Anyone in a game full of less skilled players can do well in lane, but that doesn't always translate to a win. The reason to smurf is to learn how to translate a winning lane into a winning game. Or, how to make your own individual play that is better than everyone else, make the game a winning game.

This can actually be very hard to do. I had a game on my Riven smurf account where I went 45-9-3 (our team had 49 kills total). The other team had 54 kills total and was winning every lane but my lane. So, in order to win that game, I needed to carry each laner and put them in a position to knock down turrets. It was insanely hard, because every one of my teammates was not going to be useful, all were 1-10 or worse, and carrying the game took a lot of work (basically, the only way my team could win a lane is if their opponent was dead or not there). 

So, I basically went around eliminating any possibility for the other team to fight mine, by killing all of them. Usually it was just killing two or so at a time, but I did get a 1v5 Penta, but noticed around that time, that I was falling off and needed to end fast or I wouldn't be able to carry the game.

Anyways, yes, smurfing helps teach how to carry.

No... The situation you are "practicing" for is something that will never happen in a ranked game or otherwise.  The skill level gap you are talking about is much to extreme. True everyone has had a feeder or two on their team but that was because they were having a bad game.  The people who you are teamed with AND against are people who don't even know their champions combos or positioning.

You are just beating up on people who don't know how to play the game, nothing more in that scenario.

Edit: What you are merely saying is cognitive dissonance.  Where you know what you are doing is wrong, but are trying to rationalize it as practice.

Though I personally don't think Smurfing really helps you, this is just wrong. Here are several very realistic situations in Gold+ you could face that mirror those situations:

1) Other lane(s) are failing and you have to compensate (gank? Stall and bring pressure to your lane so they can farm?)
2) Team isn't very well coordinated and you have to guide them through plays (push mid turret quick and move down to bot)
3) You're fed and you need to translate that to a win. What do you do? Ganking, pushing, shifting pressure...
4) Encouraging discouraged teammates
5) How do you compensate for a skillgap between you and your teammates? Sure the skill gap may be smaller but even in Gold, I can meet people who are having a bad day or rough game and the negative mentality ends up making them play very poorly. Which introduces two very important questions: how can I encourage them and raise their level of play? How can I put them in a position to do better after their rough start?

These are the sort of things, not my own individual skill, that have really carried me through ranked games. I mean, sure, I have games where I snowball and start taking charge but I don't play play-makers. I main Veigar. I support frequently. I'm rarely in a position to single hanedly kill 2-3 people or make game-changing plays or take turrets. So, instead, I have to make my play revolve around my team. Which often times means dealing with a team that's doing poorly and translating that to a win.


That said, I still think it's probably better to practice all of that with players on your own level but the idea that it's just a rationalization is wrong. Also, I don't think he "knows" what he's doing is wrong so the cognitive dissonance thing is pretty moot.

I'm sorry, but you can't say that.  You are practicing with people who are just leaning, and you will never play in that environment in ranked.  Learn to carry in a normal game.  I can jump into a level 1 match, play AD TF and do the same thing, that won't make me better, it will just make me an A-hole. And cause a bunch of newbies to think AD TF is viable.

It is like saying if I am a mid to low level soccer player, change my name, and join a peewee soccer team it will teach me to be a better player.  No, putting in my hours and learning the game will.

what do you mean, no?

He means no. Smurfing teaches you nothing but how to beat up on players way worse than you.

The purpose of smurfing is not to learn.
but your not playing against bad players your playing against other smurfs

It's a mix of smurfs and new players, generally.

So, here's the thing: they're STILL all terrible. People don't make smurfs to learn. They make smurfs when they're frustrated with Ranked and want to feel better about themselves. These players are still really bad, or they wouldn't be doing it. There are smurfs made for other reasons, but they are few and far between. Most smurfs are simply a way for someone without the skill to climb in Ranked to feel better about themselves by beating up low-level players.

For the sake of argument, let's say that you were playing against legitimately good players who were smurfing. Say it's somebody your level or better. What have you gained by smurfing? You're playing against someone you probably could anyway normally... just without all Runes, Masteries and Summoners. Does that somehow teach you and make you better?
so your saying that Turtle The Cat who has about 3 smurfs that are in challenger is a bad player?

Not at all. I said smurfs for other purposes are few and far between. His are examples. He made smurfs for the sake of getting multiple accounts to Challenger. That's a cool goal, and he did it.

Answer my question, though. Do you think that fighting players you could fight on your main, but simply on lower level accounts, somehow teaches you the game better?
no, but the reason I want to make a smurf is to (I know this is going to sound dumb) make it to gold and to hopefully get to diamond someday
Why do you think a smurf will help you do that? What do you expect to learn? If your goal is personal improvement, there are better ways to approach it.

Smurfing is what you do when your main is 0 LP and you are in division 5.  If I had 1 LP for each time someone names their main and it's exactly that, I"d be #1 spot in challenger.  Also when I find people trolling normals, guess what?  0 LP plat 5 or whatever.  Shit is sad.

I have an argument that I don't see here. I've heard a joke I liked: 'I'm plat amumu, but i'm bronze with every one else'. It reminds me of the point I wanted to make.

 If you focused on only one or two champs to get you to level 30 and to whatever normals hidden mmr that you are currently rated at and playing against; You may find it difficult to play new champs against that same skill level of people. 

It may be very difficult to learn other champs because you are playing them at noob skill level against people who are playing with their main champs at whatever rating you reached with your skilled champions. Might be that it would be better if your different champs had different mmr ratings. Like the new teambuilder suggests that it takes into consideration. 

Having  a smurf would give you a skill level reset so you would have an oppoturnity to learn other champions that you are not able to learn effectively on your main account due to complete lack of skill at the champ or champions in question.

There is one more think I want to add to this.  If you REALLY want to get better and not just beat up on people who are worse than you say this, "I suck because i'm not at master tier... what could I have done to be better" no matter what happens in a game, blame yourself.  The second you think it was 100% the other guy's fault is when you think you were perfect and are not getting better.

When I want to get better I replay all of my games and hit myself for messing up, especially on the little stuff!  Even if I was 18/2/11 what could have I don't better? Could I have been 25/0/20 if I made a few better plays? Or maybe I should have died a few more times giving my team a few more team kills.
